Casandra & David PerezWhen arriving at this b&b I thought it looked cute. Little garden out front with a little fountain, wrap-around porch and Victorian style home. Made me feel welcome. Trying to open the front door, it was locked. You had to ring the doorbell and there greeted Ms. Cindy, the owner, by saying welcome home!!. She had a warm welcoming smile, truly excited we made it, and you could tell she loved people. She sat us down asked if we wanted anything to drink and then we discussed what the best places are to visit and were she recommended. She is truly awesome! Bet accommodating and wants us to have as much fun as we can! She gave us a mini tour and brought us into our room. She explained how to work the AC and the fan and let us get on our way. My girlfriend and I are celebrating our 2 year anniversary and the next time we come up here I will definitely stay here. Btw, in the morning she cooked us all breakfast and used real, that's right, REAL products. Eggs were not in a box, she picked her own veggies and herbs. The dishes were amazing and the group shared a few laughs. She has successfully ran her b&b and it is my pleasure to be sharing my experience to you all!!My husband and I stayed at the Cedar House Inn for one night during our Honeymoon December 25th 2011. We stopped in St Augustine and had made arrangements for the night with Cyndi the Inn Owner. Cyndi greeted up promptly upon arrival and we all sat in her lovely Victorian Parlor for a chat. She gave us wonderful recommendations for sightseeing and was above and beyond helpful and charming. When we arrived at our room we were stunned, Gorgeous! With an antique clawfoot tub. If you are fortunate enough to stop in this beautiful historic city please stay at The Cedar House Inn, for you will not regret it. What an experience and wonderful start to our Honeymoon. The service was superior, food amazing and location to die for.We arrived at the Cedar House Inn and were welcomed by Cyndi into her beautiful house as if we had been friends for decades. She sat us down, gave us the best tips on what to do around St. Augustine, showed us around the Inn and made us feel so very welcome and at home. We had read on Trip Advisor about her wonderful breakfasts, but we never would have imagined (until the next morning) how correct the reviews were, until we tasted them ourselves. We stayed for several days, and each day we enjoyed a totally different breakfast experience from Cyndi and help from Gina! Each day after coming back from our "tourist" trip, we were welcomed back by Cyndi as she was getting the Inn ready for the Christmas light displays and she always stopped to ask about our day, offer us a beverage or some fresh baked cookies. One night we had brought back a loaf of fresh bread, and Cyndi even toasted it for us, served on a platter with her "special" datil jelly while my wife and I spent 4 hours finishing up a puzzle they had in the living room (with some excellent wine to boot)! We stayed in the Vizcaya, and was so pleased with the decore, coziness, cleanliness and warmth of the room. After each meal, we would return to the room to find it all made up, fresh linens, clean trash bins and even my shoes were tucked away neatly (Cudos on that)! We love that there is an internal and external entrance to each room, plus climate control for each room! We really enjoyed all that St. Augustine has to offer, never felt unsafe walking around town at night, and visited some incredible sites and monuments. Please make sure to take the trolley ride around town, it sure helps you understand about the history of St. Augustine! When we return, we will only be staying at the Cedar House Inn, thank you so very much CyndiThis is a great place.  Highly recommended.  Check out the reviews on tripadvisor.All I have to say is Wow!!.   We loved the B&B.  Cyndi is a wonderful host.  She and her assistant Gina made us feel like we were staying with family.  Breakfast was to die for.  We will definitely be back.

The third star is for location and the wonderful sundeck that overlooks Matanzas bay. Otherwise, below average rooms, the bathrooms need some updating and it smells a bit musty. Additionally, we actually went to another hotel down the road to inquire about vacancy, apparently, they have a nice network among hotels in St Augustine and they refer each other business in the event that one of them have no vacancy. So the nice lady in the front counter at the other hotel actually called around until she found a room at another hotel willing to honor the AAA rate - it so happened it was the Monterrey. So we drive down the road to the Monterrey to check in and we encounter a snooty Eastern European dude that promptly claimed that we must have misunderstood because that was not what he committed to over the phone. Unfortunately, he forgot that we are in America and here, we are entitled to become ugly Americans when some idiot wants to start playing games and jacking up prices on a whim. So after a brief argument and some reminders about customer service, our willingness to contact company headquarters and AAA to log complaints he finally understood our plain English and honored the rate he had quoted over the phone when the fine lady made the reservation for us. Bad service and dismal conditions knock this place down to one star review, but location bumps it up significantly. Having he luxury of not worrying about drinking and driving in the Historical district is simply priceless.We've ALWAYS stayed here while in St. Augustine, and while the accommodations weren't the absolute best, the location was! Can walk everywhere from here and close to the places We love. I've definitely givin' this a upgrade , the new owners have completely redone this Inn, & would highly recommend it if you haven't been here in a while. We were pleasantly surprised with the upgrade.Having been helped by a not so nice person at the front desk, we figured it would be better when we got to our room. The price for the room wasn't bad but it wasn't great either. The room was beyond outdated, shabby and the bathroom was worse. You pay for hard to get parking... FAIL. The only pro to this place is it has a great balcony overlooking the bay and its right next door to our favorite Mexican joint in St. A - Acapulco. So we can drink our pitcher of Margaritas and walk right over. Since those are really the only redeeming values of the place if you don't care about the bay, go elsewhere.I don't know about the rest of these reviewers but we had a perfectly fine experience here. The location CANNOT be beat. Short walk to absolutely everything. It was great to be able to bring our dog as well. I was worried that it would be a dive but it isn't! Maybe we just got a good room but other than it being fairly tiny and awkwardly furnished it was clean and everything works. That is really all I'm asking for when I get an $85 a night room a block from St. George street with a view of the bay and Castillo de San Marco! I will definitely stay here again. There are extra fees for parking and having a pet but it still rolls out to be the best deal in town!Total beach motel POS.  For just a bit more money you could stay in a nice place.  Water leaking from the ceiling..... just all around dirty.  PassLocation and a view. Thats all I needed.I must say that the location did appeal to me as this hotel is in the historic district and has a trolley stop in front of it.  It's a short walk to almost everything downtown.  I booked 6 nights.  When I arrived, the front desk female was outside screaming at another worker under the carport.  She completed her tirade and went inside.  I waited a few minutes to ensure she composed herself thinking I was doing her a favor.  I assumed  that she would be embarrased knowing that I had witnessed her ill-behavior. He tone with me was short and almost abrasive.  Assuming she was still worked up. I cut her some slack and didn't put her in her place.  Paying the $7/night for parking was a surprise to me.  She said that it was in the print on-line so don't tell me you don't know.  My reply, again trying to be nice, was simply that I must've missed it.  Surely, she must be correct.  Having now returned home, I have checked there website and NO WHERE is is listed that there is a fee for parking.  I had called 4 days earlier to make arrangments for a first floor room, explaining to a male with a mid-eastern accent  that an elderly aunt was meeting me there, arriving separately and she had knee trouble.  The female checking me in stated that that couldn't be because I was on the second floor.  I actually had to pull the call record up on my cell phone before she believed me.  She then made a big deal about getting me a first floor room.  She completely flipped out with the news that there would be 2 cars and I had no intention of  paying for 2 parking spots.  She stated that they never tow anyone anyways so it would be fine.  I went to the room. It was 56 degrees and took 2.5 hours to warm up.   It was older and dark, but I didn't expect more given the price for the location.  Day two - came back to the room after touring and found my window curtains wide open with the lights on and no washclothes. You could see right into the room from the sidewalk for anyone walking by.   I went to the office and got some washclothes.  I also asked that they keep my drapes drawn during the day.  She took a note on a piece of paper and the next day I found the drapes closed and had washclothes.  Day 4 I had similar service but found dizzy ants running all over the sink ledge and wall of the bathroom.  I went to the office, met a middle-eastern man.  I told him what I found and asked if someone could spray while we left for dinner.  He said "Do you want to move to another room?".  I told him that I was only there 2 more nights and I didn't think it was necessary with the type of ant that it was.  I really felt it was a fluke and if they could simply spray I would get over it.  I didn't see bugs anywhere else that day.  He uttered no aplogy nor did he look or act surprised.   Day 5 I found the drapes open, short 1 washcloth and hair that didn't belong to either of us in the sink.  I didn't bother getting a washcloth.  The day I left the ants were all over the dresser and there was a large winged bug in my sheets.  By large I mean over 1/2" in length.  Enough is enough.  This was a major FAIL.  Thankfully this was not a vacation where I planned on spending any time in a room.This place has an amazing location. It's right near the Castillo de San Marcos and (more importantly) short walking distance to the historic Old Town and all it's shops and restaurants. The location is worth it (and $40-$50 cheaper than the Hilton which appeared to be the only other pet friendly place on the bay) but there is a definite ick factor. This place could be one heck of a boutique hotel if they updated it. The best I can say is that I didn't way up with my nose completely blocked from dust allergies. Oh and they did recently paint the outside. Time for them to do the inside!A dump. I'm giving it one star because you don't offer no stars. If you want to be assigned the crap-de-la-crap room, book through Expedia. Oh, don't bring your SUV tank here -- the parking is tight to say the least and not free. Only positives are great location and Mary's Kitchen on-site.

I was very pleasantly surprised by this Days Inn. It was a fantastic price when everything else was outrageous. It's only like a 15 minute walk from everything you want to do! The walls are very thin though, between the rooms and to the outside... Our neighbors were INCREDIBLY inconsiderate. Other than that the front desk staff was nice and they have a pool! There is also a Denny's INSIDE the hotel! Life saver! Honestly I've never stayed at a Day's Inn but I would stay here again!Me and my husband do a Valentine's Weekend trip to St. Augustine every year. This year a lot of the hotels out there prices up WAY higher than usual so we booked this Days Inn because the price was decent and close to everything (literally walking distance). When we arrived to check in the woman at the counter was very friendly. We requested a top floor room, because I have an irrational fear of being on first floors and people driving into the room lol! Our room was in a separate back side building and on second floor like we asked. When I walked in I was amazed at how large the room was! And the bathroom as well! The bed was a comfy King. Nice flat screen tv. Shower water stayed hot the whole time. Big full length mirrors. The lights were a little dim, but not a big deal. Very quiet area. I was highly impressed with this hotel. Especially for the price. Literally connected in the parking lot is a "double tree" hotel that costs double the price, in the exact same area.. And I doubt the rooms are much better! I definitely recommend this hotel and will for sure be using it next year! The fountain of youth is literally a block away!! And George street and everything over near the fort is literally a nice scenic 15 min walk! Not to mention theres a Denny's attached to this Days Inn, a couple blocks down is a McDonald's, Pizza Hut and Zaxbys. When I checked out there was a different woman working the counter and she was extremely nice as well! So overall great customer service! I was hesitant because of some of the bad reviews, but honestly most people who leave bad reviews are whiny spoiled people who don't appreciate anything. I'm glad I went with my gut and chose this place! Will be back!! :)This is a hotel you can stay at if you just want a place to sleep & you're out and about most of the entire day. The rooms are dingy with a musty smell almost like a wet dog had lived in & slept there for an entire month or so! Thanks to Febreze it made the room smell fresh but we still have to spray every so often! One thing's for sure- i ain't coming back!Rooms were nice, not too bad. Bathroom was small. Shower only, no tub. The room smelled at little weird, like a wet mildewey smell. Showers could be a little cleaner, but not too bad. Breakfast till 930.Had a great time. Nice place, room could be cleaner. But I blame my boyfriend for getting drunk and peeing in my shoes.I let my boyfriend pick this hotel and that was my first mistake. This was the single worst hotel I've stayed at. It was disgusting and needed a much better cleaning (there were long hairs on the shower wall, etc)However, the kicker was the fact that our room was next to the maintenance room for the hotel. It was easily 30 degrees warmer in the hallway outside our room. It took four hours of continuous air conditioner use for it to palatable. We turned it off for an hour in the morning while we were getting ready, and the room was already miserable. Seriously, if you book this hotel as a last resort, and get the room 215, sleep in your car. It would be a better experience.old --  motel, but within walking distance to downtown... no free breakfast.So good so far. Friendly staff. Melinda greeted us.However, it pretty much went downhill from there. The location is pretty cool and located next to a coffee shop and really not too far from downtown. We parked at a parking deck downtown and it was just as far to walk to downtown from the deck as it would have been to just walk from the motel to the deck. We could have saved ourselves some money I guess. The king-size bed is "like our old bed" as my wife put it and that means she did not like it. She also does not like that the sheets do not fit very well. I have to agree. They keep coming off the bed and it's hard to get them go back on. I think they are perhaps a size too small. The front desk has a sign that states there is a safe in the room and a dollar is added to the room fee for this "convenience" because they have had break ins before. There is no gym on the premises in case you didn't look very hard. There is no breakfast because there is seriously a Denny's restaurant in the motel right by the pool. It is so right by the pool that the diners get a view of the pool. I was not happy about that. I don't want people eating and watching me swim and I don't want to eat and watch people swim. I don't understand why this was a good idea. It just makes me think some old pervert was thinking about watching some girls or something while he enjoyed his bacon and pancakes. Really creepy...On top of this there was a large group of young people (think about 9-12 years old) all here on charter buses. They were swarming the parking lot when we returned and all in the way. They were all by the pool at 9:30 at night. You could hear them going up and down the outside hallway at night. Just not a great experience thus far. The staff are all friendly still, but there are a lot of irritating things about this motel. There is a pretty nice coffee shop next door, but the place is also pretty expensive. The internet is pretty awful. The first night we were here it was very, very laggy and it is not secured at all. The motel is located within walking distance of downtown, but you can expect a pretty decent hike.Having spent years in the hotel business I know what it takes to run a hotel and how hard it is and it is very unlike me to write bad things about hotels because I know first hand that "things happen" and I am extremely forgiving.  This hotel was just about the most disgusting hotel I have ever been to in more ways than one.I'm not going to write a book so here are my issues:-Clerk wrote down my whole credit card number on registration paperwork (major no-no and total breach of security procedures)-Seedy clientele-Room was filthy trash from previous guest, floor not vacuumed, sticky stuff, just gross-BLOOD ON THE MATTRESS!!!!-Called to complain to the manager, no response, called corporate, no responseDon't let them ruin your vacation...The night before coming to St Augustine (for the first time) I began to search for places to stay (near or in historic district) and I began to think either there is a special event going on or this is a very popular town... because I can't find a room.  I was able to find rooms by a couple of Interstate 95 exits (15 - 20 miles away)... no thanks.Turns out there was a special event going one which is why it was so hard to find a hotel room in the historic district;  Flagler College was having their graduation ceremonies that same weekend.I ended up finding a room on the AMEX travel website for the Days Inn Historic Downtown.  Searching info on the hotel didn't scare me off but then again it certainly didn't excite me either.  Then again this was less than a mile from the action so I rolled the dice.  And oh boy, did I "crap" out.Entered the lobby for check-in... other than it looking a bit dated, it was clean and the two girls at the front desk were helpful, friendly and offered to be available if  had any questions or concerns or needed any recommendations.The room wasn't terrible but then again I was just hoping the room is mold and bed bug free.  Of course the traditional musty smell (like many of these old hotels) was present.  Basically it was a typical room like any other older Days Inn.If I stopped here I'd rate them a 3 star (keeping in mind 3 stars is not bad;  after all it is "A-OK")... unfortunately there is a but in there that dropped me to a 2 star and I think my 2 star is being generous.My issue had to do with an outside stairway near out 2nd floor room.  This hotel is an old style hotel with no interior hallways (all room doors are exposed to the outside).  After I turned in the keys and checked out, I returned to the room, grabbed my bags and shut the door behind me.  When we turned a corner to enter the stairwell there was a lot of water accumulated at the top of the stairs... And yes, I lost my footing and yes, I fell down the stairs.  Luckily my good reflexes and with my quick thinking I grabbed a rail before any real bodily damaged occurred (though one of my bags did get a little wet).  I was shaken up but other than uneasy nerves and embarrassment I wasn't injured so I left.  I did noticed they had one of those yellow warning signs but of course it was off to the side and not noticeable coming around the corner to the stairs.  In hindsight, I should've told the clerk on-duty so an hour later I decided to call and let them know... not for a discount, not for a refund, not to threaten a lawsuit... I called so they could prevent someone else from getting injured or worse yet killed (which is not far-fetched).  I got the manager and he attitude was SHOCKING... took no responsibility and would not acknowledge anything wrong.  He just said I should've come in if I had a problem.  I agreed but take care of the problem, put a better sign out, put more than one sign, put a warning at the bottom of the stairs too, find out why the water was there in the first place, just do something.  He was just defensive and nonchalant of the whole situation.  Terrible manager.This place could use a good power-washing. For the money (we paid $65) it wasn't a bad place to stay. It just wasn't very nice. Call me crazy, but I think a hotel can be inexpensive and still be nice. The outside door to our room seriously needed to be repainted. The shower (in the VERY small bathroom) at some point had been repaired and the caulk job was poorly done. There was gum stuck to the carpet near our bed. The cable, attached to the bulky, out-dated TV had many channels that were out of service or had a picture but no sound.On the upside, the pool area was nice, and having a Denny's on site was a bonus. (We ate there and the food was pretty good.) Overall I give our stay a resounding, "just barely ok."We've stayed in other Days Inns before. This was by far the worst. Sign out front said "new look". That meant a fresh coat of paint, poorly done. Paint splatters all over fixtures, light switch covers were dingy and didn't cover holes in wall. Shower needed complete replacing, but only had a patch job. Price for one night exceeded the appearance and quality. Don't expect a lot of you do stay here. You can put lipstick on a pig. But, it's still a pig. Front desk staff were meh. Didn't even ask how our stay was when checking out.Booked off Priceline. Expected something worth the over $100 I paid to stay, but found the room worse than a no star hotel. Not only is the room rundown and the bed lumpy and noisy, the bathroom and sink had hair all over, near the coffee maker, on the bathtub (which had caulk and yellow stains all over) and black hairs on the bath towels. Dusty in a lot of spots, dark and muggy like a jail cell, cold tile floors with chips in them, messy plywood instead of an actual cupboard on the front of the sink, and horrible lumpy pillows. I'd say they should be paying me to stay in this room for a night. I'm scared to even look under the bed...The beds in this place are so bad that we felt like we were trying to sleep on something left over from the Spanish Inquisition.  Hard, lump, broken down.  The shower got water on everything but the person trying to take a shower, I've had better showers in a truck stop than we had here.  For the price they ought to at least have some kind of free breakfast.  We stayed there during the 2014 Pirate Gathering and the only good thing about it was its proximity to a great place for morning coffee, City Coffee which is right across the street from them.  I will never stay there again.The bad reviews here are not very fair. It is clean and despite being close to the road it is quiet. Staff were friendly and helpful. The rooms must have been recently remodeled because they are more modern than the images suggest. I would stay here again, for sure.For twice the price of historic Howard Johnson you get smaller, less maintained rooms, no continental breakfast and a staff that while friendly is completely clueless. I have been going to St Augustine every 12 months for over a decade and this is the first time I have made the mistake of staying here. Never again.This place needs a deep cleaning. The room smelled moldy. The room was humid and the carpet disgusting. The bathroom was not very clean and did not smell good. I've stayed at other days inn and never had such a bad experience. I brought the issues up to management and was told I could not be moved to another room. I went to a neighboring La Quinta booked a room and had a much better experience. I was so upset by the way I was treated by the days in management that I went ahead me called corporate. They said they would take note of it but the days inn are independently owned and they could not do much for me. I them went ahead and called my credit card explained what was going on and they agreed to declined payment to the days inn. I do not suggest anyone stay there. There are other better hotels in the same area for the same price.This place is awful. Not because of the rooms but the things they let happen. At 2:00 the people above us has their cars music on the max with loud bass. These stupid guys started banging on our window then when we let our dog out someone came and pissed right next to him. Then in our laundry someone put their dirty boxers in with it! This is only one night getting in at 7:30!!!!Exactly what you'd expect from a Days Inn-- a decent, clean, affordable place to stay for the night.  A non-smoking room with two double beds cost us $99 a night.  My friend and I checked here after dinner and a stroll in historic St. Augustine.  We stopped at two separate Best Westerns closer to the historic area but they were both completely booked for the night.  It's within a 10 minute drive to the historic area, the manager at the front desk we polite, the room was clean, there was free Wi-fi and the beds were comfortable.Questionable... Ants, maybe a roach, dirty, dirty dirty!  Hard to tell if it was New Year's Eve fireworks or gun shots... I saw a dope needle on the sidewalk.  But it's cheap and close....about a 10-15 minute walk to historic downtown.  Will definitely pay more next time to stay elsewhere....never staying here again.
review_content_20: I'd choose somewhere else given the chance, mainly because it was overpriced for the room condition.  The floors and sheets were clean and the bed was comfortable, but there were some pretty gross things about it.  The room smelled musty.  The door stuck so badly we had to kick it in.  The coffee maker was disgusting, as were the light switches - embedded dirt.  Floor boards were falling apart.  Wifi was slow, and the vending machine on one side of the place had nothing in it.  I'm not picky, but for this price ($100) I expected a lot more.  Everything else was full but next time I will drive a ways out to go somewhere else.

review_content: Great lunch experience-would go back and try dinner! It is located right downtown in a quaint bed and breakfast. The food was amazing- they had fresh bread with wonderful oil and vinegar that make there with roasted garlic. We had the fried cauliflower, which I HIGHLY recommend. My husband doesn't even like cauliflower and he devoured this app!  My husband got the nom pizza special and I got the mozzarella chicken sandwich. Everything was delicious and the service was excellent.Restaurant review: This is truly a gem in St Augustine and very much off the beaten path. We literally stumbled upon it just walking by! It's without a question on the old fashioned side of things, but hey, what did you come to this town for! It's set in an old fashioned inn.- EASILY THE BEST CEVICHE IVE EVER HAD. I mean, they just know their ceviche. Nothing else to add really other than, it's spectacular! Loaded with seafood, avocado and served nicely in a glass.- BREAD AND ROASTED GARLIC - here I am really questioning myself, how did I not come up with this myself. Just cut off the stem from the garlic and roast it in olive oil in the oven. So simple, so good.- SEAFOOD DISHES ARE AMAZING. Cod is great. The Chilean sea bass is loaded with freshness and flavor. - CREME BRULEE IS ODD. I say odd, because it tasted absolutely nothing like a CREME brulee, but was very good. Reminded me of some Eastern European pastries.- WINE PRICING IS GREAT. I knew very well most of the wines on their menu and must admit, they did not up charge much at all! If you like Chardonnay, ZD Chardonnay is spectacular and one of my favorites.To sum it up, you better be putting this spot on your must go list of dinners in St Augustine. You do need a reservation by the way.My husband and I spent Valentine's night at Old City House Inn and had dinner at the restaurants.  First the Inn, it was the MOST comfortable bed I may have ever slept in!  Lovely room overlooking the Lightner Museum.  The street was busy when you wanted it to be and quiet when you didn't.  The host was so charming and pleasant and I LOVED everyone's accents.  It was an absolutely enjoyable experience!  Dinner was another story.  We had made the reservation for dinner in the restaurant at the same time we made our room reservation.  We were verbally confirmed for an 8pm dinner.  When we went in to have some wine and cheese, complimentary for being a guest, at 5pm that evening, my husband checked on our dinner reservation.  There was none we were told and then they said that they were full for the evening.  My husband said that we had made the reservation at the same time as the room so they then realized we were guests and found us a table at 8pm.  For some reason early in the dinner, our server seemed to develop a chip on his shoulder about our dining experience.  I don't know if it was when he asked my husband if we were ready to order and he said "please give us a few minutes" or what it was, but all of a sudden, BAM!  It seemed he was really short and uninterested in us as patrons.  We heard another waiter explaining in vivid detail what was good on the menu, the specials, his favorites, etc... but our waiter couldn't wait to take our order and be gone from our table.  Talk about poor table side manners!   In the past our meals have always been really good. My zarzuela, or fish stew, was delish.  My husband ordered cod and scallops.  Unfortunately, when my husband went to flake the fish, it ended up being a blob of mushy fish.  You know, once fish isn't just right, you shy away.  When the waiter came by the table to ask how our meal was, my husband explained that the fish was not really fresh as far as he could tell.  The server asked if he'd like something else, and my husband said if you could just give me two more scallops, that would be great.  Right away, the server informed us that there was going to be an upcharge since scallops were so much more than cod.  We get that, but two!?!?! The waiter actually brought four additional ones with no mention of a charge.  Well, we finished out meal, and the waiter never even asked if we'd like desert.  Like I said, for some reason he wanted nothing to do with us even BEFORE the cod and scallop incident.When the waiter brought the check, there it was, and additional eight dollar charge for the scallops!  When my husband questioned the waiter he said "this is what the chef said to charge, don' t blame me for this!" Rather interesting since he mentioned the "up-charge" even before he spoke to the chef.  Either we weren't the first to complain about fish, or did he plant the seed in the chef's mind.  Hard to say, but we were more than happy to get out of there that night!Breakfast the next morning was wonderful, so I have to believe that even though the fish was smelly, our server, who shall not be named, but has a handle bar mustache, was even stinkier.We had a very nice room here. Al guests get a complementary glass of wine or beer and a cheese platter. Really great and tasteful. The room we had (a kings room) was spacy with good beds. The staff was really friendly and helpful. I'll would love to come back again.We just spent one night at this fabulous hidden gem . Wonderful breakfast and very friendly staff ...will definitely be back !Stopped in here on a tasting tour.  First off I loved the way the inn feels.  It is a taste of old St Augustine.  We were given a delicious appetizer of rice and peas with shrimp on top. They were really yummy.  We also had a sample of one of their house wines, which was delicious.  After hearing about the Inn itself we are considering coming and staying here for Christmas for a couple of nights.  We will definitely come back and try more foods from their menu as well.We stayed at the inn and the rooms and service was amazing.  I wish I could live here.I. am. in. love. with this charming place.My husband and I had originally planned to spend the weekend for our 2 year anniversary in August. But that was cut short as I came down with a horrible migraine and head-cold the first night. The first impression of the Inn we had the first time around was 3 out of 5 stars, all because our room was doused, I mean literally infused, with some kind of pungent air freshener. My husband and I are very sensitive to fragrances, scented candles, air fresheners... mainly artificial scents. I think trying to sleep in the room the first night had triggered my migraine and made head cold even worse.We were sad to leave the next morning because it was evident that I wasn't gonna get any better to enjoy the anniversary weekend. The innkeeper was very nice enough to offer us a voucher to return another time to make up for the second night we already had paid for.Just this past weekend, my husband decided to spring the surprise of taking me back to St. Augustine and we used the voucher for a Friday night. We did give the inn keeper the request, this time, to make sure our room wasn't sprayed with any kind of air freshener.  I was nervous about that and even packed enough migraine medicine.... however upon our entrance to the room, it was perfect! He listened! We were thrilled with it and we were able to enjoy our stay thoroughly without any headaches!The entire building is so adorable, the lounge & bar is romantically lit at night, the dining room is cozy, and the outdoor sitting area by the small gardens is somewhat exotic.When you go to the lounge room, they bring you a complimentary tray of fine cheeses and crackers. I was so excited to have tried some fine cheese as I had never tried brie! Yum! They have wine, beer, and some hard liquor. With the candle-lighting, my husband and I felt like we had just started dating. The servers are extremely nice and well mannered.For the complimentary breakfast (between 9-10am only), they bring out 2-3 courses with a plate at a time. We absolutely loved it. The first breakfast we had was a lot of fruit, eggs, and waffles. And the second breakfast was similar but minus the waffles and more meat and an omelet. We think they offer different kinds of breakfast every morning and working with what is fresh in season.The Old City House Inn has a lot of the things that many other inns in the area don't have like: sufficient parking (some inns have NONE!), true history (some inns are cliche or overdone or even shady!), excellent food and innkeeping service, prime location (right next to the luxurious Casa Monica Hotel, Flagler College, Lightner Museum), and just a few blocks away from the touristy hustle bustle of St. George Street.We absolutely love this inn and will definitely come back to this inn whenever we are in St. Augustine. It's a home away from home!Excellent food and very attentive and friendly service. The chef went to each table and made sure the customers were satisfied. We had the zarzuela and the Herb Crusted Chilean Sea Bass with dill lemon gras sauce over lightly fried yuca and sauteed vegetables. The dessert, Italian style cheesecake recommended by our waitress, Peggy, was fantastic. It was light and fluffy with a salty Carmel crust.One of the best meals and overall restaurant experience we've had period.Great food and service. The presentation of the food is outstanding too. We were so pleasantly surprised by the entire experience. The dining room is quaint and cozy and on our list to visit when it's colder outside.This place is so unique. Rooms are very nice, we had a room with a huge bedroom, spa bath tub.Three words come to mind when reflecting on my Old City House Inn & Restaurant dining experience: Flavorful, Inventive and Accommodating. Let me explain... We went here the evening before Thanksgiving, because let's be honest, who wants to cook a big meal the night before a full day's worth of cooking?!?! Well, we didn't, so my brother looked for a spot on Open Table and decided that based on the reviews and that we could get a reservation at our desired timing, that this was the spot. We parked just a few blocks away in a free after 6 p.m. lot and strolled into a cozy restaurant and I could already tell we would be pleased. They had our table ready and waiting for us, and while the restaurant is small, they maximize the space with all the table formations they have. Our waitress was friendly and kept the meal well paced. The food was flavorful - while you felt like you were stepping into a comfortable place with comfortable choices, the chef certainly knows the combinations to keep your palette interested. Our bottle of wine arrived with some hot out of the oven bread with roasted garlic, herb infused olive oil and balsamic vinegar as toppings. We were hooked at the first bite and devoured the entire plate of bread! All entrees come with a house salad, but I was able to upgrade to the soup of the day (tomato basil bisque) as I had a sore throat and was in the mood for a soup versus salad. The soup was an ample serving and stayed hot from the first to the last spoonful. I love me some goat cheese and decided I wanted to swap sides, which again they had no problem with, as I prefer roasted potatoes to squash. The presentation of all of our meals was first class - another sign of the chef's comfort with food and its artistic display on the plates (not only ours, but those of the other diners we saw coming by). I ate my whole meal, but certainly didn't save room for dessert, although I'm sure it would be equally impressive. On the way out, we saw the previously Yelped about outdoor patio space and on a warmer evening, I think this little oasis would be the perfect spot for pre or post dinner drinks, even if you still wanted the actual dining room experience for dinner itself. Word to the wise - make reservations as since they are small, it would likely be tough to just walk in on a more popular night to dine out. We thoroughly enjoyed our meal, so much so that we were still talking about it the next day!While a couple of the dishes were good and the desserts were good, my swordfish was so dry it was inedible. But what really upset me was that it was my parents' 50th anniversary and I called ahead to tell them, asking if they could do anything nice. I talked to someone who assured me they would make it special. Our waitress, however, didn't even know it was their anniversary and when I told her it was, she still charged us for the desserts. I would not recommend this place to anyone.Sooooo good and great service. If you're stuck on ordering the sea bass is delicious!Took my wife for her birthday. Kind if hidden and off the main drag . Blown away by the vegetable beef soup made with filet mignon. Surprised by the Tamarindo sorbet to cleanse the palate in between soup , salad and entree. The beef tenderloin was simply out if this world for this area. I thought I was back in the City or in the Midwest. Flavor , texture , presentation was a chart topper. Service was very good .. Don't miss it if your in St Augustine . I'm going back...For my birthday last weekend, a dear friend of mine took me to St. Augustine for the day. Upon our arrival, the first place that we went was to Old City House Inn and Restaurant. If it hadn't been so hot, I definitely would have preferred to sit on the beautiful patio, but that shall have to wait until the Fall or early Spring. From what I've seen of the dinner menu, it's rather expensive, but if you go here for lunch, you are provided with a "Bites" menu which is basically smaller portions at a lower price (around $6) per plate. The one thing that irked me about the menu was the amount of items that are unfriendly to those of us with lactose issues/allergies. I don't need special treatment, but I expect menus to be somewhat well rounded so everyone can have an enjoyable meal. In any case, I digress, this did not take away from my experience on this day, but did limit my choices. I had my heart set on a salad. I debated the Tri Colore Salad, which is radicchio, arugula (my absolute favorite green), endive, and white balsamic vinaigrette. I just couldn't bring myself to order this plate at $9 when I could get all of those ingredients so much cheaper at the store. What I ended up ordering was the Melon, Artichoke, and Chorizo Salad from the Bites menu as my appetizer. It was the perfect combination of sweet, salty, and spicy. All three flavors worked together splendidly. Along the lines of appetizers, we had also been served some rather fantastic garlic, along with olive oil and a balsamic reduction to go with our bread. The garlic was roasted while still within the clove itself and was some of the best that I've ever tasted. As we planned to walk around St. Augustine for awhile after lunch, I chose a main course that would be light on the stomach. Grilled Shrimp with polenta, which is actually listed as an appetizer, was my choice. While the polenta was a bit heavy, the shrimp was grilled to perfection. After finding out that it was my birthday, the waiter thanked me for telling him and went off to the kitchen. Just after we were given our check, he came out with a special birthday dessert: passion fruit creme brule. A spectacular end to a great birthday lunch.Nice place that used to be horrible. It's in a great location, but even so, I stopped going there after a couple of dismal overpriced meals and a business lunch where nobody got what they ordered, the food was inedible and it took us almost a half hour to get the check and correct the errors on it!  So the new owners have a lot to overcome.I think they'll do it! The food is excellent. We had a sort of tapas lunch, with wine, of course, and everything was excellent. The fried cauliflower is a treat and the cod fritters weren't fritters but large excellent pieces of cod. The star was the Spanish tortilla, which wasn't the simple egg and potato dish, but s fluffy quiche-like dish with a variety of perfect vegetables.  Dessert was their version of cheesecake, recommended by the hostess, and it was truly fine.The service was great and the price  was reasonable for the quality.  My only reservation was the interior of the restaurant, which hadn't been changed probably since the early 90s, when the old owners bought it. Very stodgy and dull. And I saw people on the street peer inside and then go away. Other than that, it's fine, highly recommended (by me!) and ... I hope they get a remodel soon.My only complaint was I couldn't stay longer! Such a fine establishment. The innkeepers have quite a gem here. The rooms are very nice, clean and comfortable. We regret missing dinner at the restaurant, but will definitely dine there next time. We had coffee and dessert, and drinks. The staff was wonderful, and each person went out of their way to accommodate us. We will back and recommend this as the ace to stay in St Augustine!I wish I could give this place a 5-star review, but it's just not going to happen yet.So this place is definitely a gem - albeit a well-known gem. Its frequented a lot, mostly by locals, sometimes by tourists. We stopped by here as a quick stop for some drinks at the bar before walking anymore in the heat (interesting fact, the week of June 27th saw an above-average solar flare). I love the way these older buildings were constructed - they are all about ventilation without the need for artificial AC. The smells coming from the kitchen about knocked us down from how mouth-watering they were!We were seated quickly even though the lunch rush was picking up. Luckily there was a table for four open, which interestingly enough is really difficult to find seeing how the restaurant is better suited for couples.One: Food was amazing. It was so fresh you could basically hear our food breathing, and the taste of everything together just made a hit with my family. I will never looked at bacon the same way again!Two: The atmosphere leaves something to be desired. There was just a certain something about the place that felt off - it may have been the wall color, it may have been the standoffish way the locals eyed everyone around them. Either way, it was dealt with and didn't take away from our overall experience.Three: The service was speedy but very quickly dropped to a crawl. And herein lies the reason for 4 stars. While we were seated and got drinks quickly, it quite literally took forever for a server to come back and either refill our drinks or take our orders. I understand a lunch rush in a touristy city in a well-known restaurant can be daunting, and I know servers always get a bad rap. Here I do have to say the restaurant for the most part really works hard for and deserves that fifth star. Once the speed during the lunch rush is resolved, I'll be giving it that extra star.Overall, price was what I expected. Free dessert wine was a nice surprise (I know my step-father said something about the speed of the service to the manager). I WILL come back to this restaurant when we're back in the city, but I'll probably be eating here before/after the lunch rush.The food was delicious - I only wish we had more of an appetite for lunch! I just had the tomato basil bisque and it was some of the best I've tasted! They also bring out bread and olive oil/vinegar with a roasted clove of garlic. It made my day - I love roasted garlic and most places do not serve an entire clove with the bread! I would love to go back for a full meal because there were quite a few great looking dishes. The ambiance was lovely as well and it was a nice quite spot for lunch before heading to the Lightner Museum and Flagler College tours!
review_content_20: This beautifully restored Inn located in the middle of the old city is welcoming and genuine. The staff have a culture reflective of the owner Juan who is passionate about services in all respects. We had a wonderful experience and highly recommend it for the experience, people, food, presentation and professionalism. We look forward to our next visit.Stayed two nights, great location. Included is a happy hour and breakfast. Worth your money staying here.  Juan is the innkeeper and made our stay here WAY WORTH WHILE!!!  TIP.... FREE PARKING AND BICYCLES! Have fun here!Excellent service and gourmet cuisine in one of Florida's most beautiful cities! Highly recommend their specials of the day! A rare find.Excellent food and service! best naturally made sangria Ive ever had in Florida. the food is very fresh and tasty.Excellent.  Looks like a stuffy little place but it is very elegant and refined.  Food was incredible.  Service was fantastic.  Small intimate setting.  Attached to a small Inn.  Small seating area so make reservations.  Also.  Parking is a nightmare so be prepared to hunt for parking.  We got lucky on a metered space right in front of the location.We stumbled upon this gem for dinner by accident. First of all, the waiter Max was attentive and delightful. Secondly, kudos to the chef. Each course was better than the last and the presentation was just beautiful. The ambiance was also very nice. I had the escargot appetizer. It was AMAZING. My husband had the crab bisque. It was out of this world. The fresh bread is served with flavored olive oil, roasted garlic and balsamic reduction. Heaven. We each had a house salad that was tasty and the perfect portion size so as not to be too filling. I had the papaya vinaigrette on mine and my husband had the sun dried tomato dressing. Again, fabulous. Max then brought us each a serving of peach sorbet served on an orange slice with mint to cleanse our palates. I've not had a palate cleansing sorbet served to me in easily the past 20 years. We each had one of the night's specials. I had the swordfish and he had the seafood past. The portions were very generous, delicious and beautifully presented. We were stuffed but how could we not have desert here?!  I had a baked wine infused pear and my husband had layered chocolate mouse cake. Both phenomenal. Our bill was right around $100. I would recommend reservations and there is parking nearby. This place is not to be missed.What can you say about perfection.  The food is outstanding as well as good service.  I had the escargot and they were perfectly cooked.  The Halibut, which was a special was out of this world.  Great little find.This is my first 5 star review because everything was excellent-service, food and ambiance. To start the roasted garlic, olive oil and balsamic with the bread is perfect, we had our 9 year old daughter with us who devoured this (always a good sign). All of the entrees come with starter salad so between the bread and salad there was no need for us to try any appetizers. They had 5 options for dressing, our favorite was the papaya dressing, it was sweet but complimented the salad well. Then came the blackberry sorbet palate cleanser to prepare for the delicious main course that was about to bless our taste buds. My husband and I had the sea bass layered on top of fried yuca and asparagus in a herb, lemon butter sauce. The flavors and cooking preparation of this dish was superb. My daughter had the filet served with potatoes au gratin and green beans - all cooked perfectly. There was no room for desert since we all cleared our plates. I highly recommend this restaurant and we will be back anytime we find ourselves in St. Augustine again.UPDATE (5/31/15): Went back to Old City House this year. Oh. My. God.It was our anniversary. Christopher upgraded our room to the St. George room, the most gorgeous room I have ever stayed in on a vacation. They left us champagne, an anniversary card and some fruit. We went to dinner at the restaurant and enjoyed a delicious meal. They surprised us with amazing cheesecake for our anniversary.If I could leave 6 stars, I would! ---This was our first time in St. Augustine. We loved staying here. The staff was very friendly and gave us great recommendations on things to do (and to avoid). Juan and Christopher, the innkeepers, were very attentive and nice. The location is perfect. It's right next to the Lightner Museum and a short walk from the fun stuff. If you sit outside for breakfast, you have a nice view of Flagler College. We loved the complimentary parking and free beach cruiser bikes to ride around town. The food is phenomenal. We decided to eat lunch after checking in. My husband had, what he called, the greatest chicken sandwich of his life. I had seared tuna - which was excellent. Breakfast the next day was fantastic. Also: The presentation of the food is beautiful. They really do have a talented chef.We also enjoyed the wine & cheese hour. Free wine/beer/cheese/fruit is always fun.Our room (the Cordova) was very clean and smelled so good. I liked how the balcony was right outside our door. The bed was comfy. My only gripe about the room would be the pillows. Maybe it's my personal preference, but I don't like really fluffy & firm pillows.Overall: 5 stars! We will be back for sure...next time longer than 2 days/1 night!Great place. I've stayed at a lot of places, this has been one of the nicest. Older building so loud pipes and outside noises and poor water pressure. All made up for with personable friendly owners, clean, location good and great food.Good service, nice presentation, but the flavors fell flat.  The seared tuna was competently done, but the service on a plate with pedestal made it tricky to share on a table already pretty crowded with a cocktail and wine and the complimentary bread (which is ok, but nothing special).  My roasted garlic salad dressing (house made) had a greasy texture that was off putting but the greens were fresh and attractive.  They served a raspberry sorbet as a little amusement between salad and main, which was a nice idea but was executed in what was becoming a pattern of "not quite right."  Our entrees took a long time to come out and showed it by having cooled beyond my taste though my companion was satisfied (I'll admit I like my food served hotter than most people care for).  He had a pork shank special that looked phenomenal, but the mushroom Marsala sauce was incredibly bland.  I had the beef tenderloin which was slightly more done than I expected but tender.  The potatoes gratin were runny on the bottom, dry in the middle, and a glob of gooey melted cheese on top.  I make better at home from leftovers.  We skipped dessert and walked down the street to the Chocolate Turlte where we were wowed with wonderfulness.I only have experienced the restaurant but I am a repeat guest.  Good, fresh food and owner Juan is a true jewel.  He makes a point to engage his guests and cares about the quality-everytime I go there, he is there and very hands on.My favorite dish is the white fish served with hearts of palm. Never had a dish that I didn't enjoy and I think this is a charming inn at its BEST!Truly a great restaurant experience with creative attention to every detail. Great wine choices at a decent price. Amazing cheesecake-a wonderful surprise that we happened upon by accident! Loved St. AugustineMy wife and I have been dining here for 20+ years. We know there have been changes in ownership over the years but the quality remains. We celebrated our anniversary there Wednesday evening with the trout and sea bass both being excellent. The portions and service were excellent too. Our secret place in the oldest city.WOW! One cannot fully express the joy of this B&B. Clean, awesome innkeeper, central location to all the shops and restaurants. This is a top notch B&B. The restaurant looks quaint and the food looked delicious. We opted for a local raw restaurant for our supper, but we had a delicious cup of fresh, homemade hot chocolate with some rock candy as a spoon. My wife FULLY enjoyed the eggs Benedict for breakfast, and they made gluten-free pancakes for me with maple syrup. A fruit cocktail was served in a cocktail glass, and endless coffee, tea and orange juice quenced our thirst.Book your next stay here, we literally had the whole inn to ourselves, only one other couple down the hall. You won't regret it!Recently, I had the unique opportunity to stay at the Old City House Inn & Restaurant located on 115 Cordova St in Saint Augustine, FL.The Old City House was originally constructed in 1873. The exterior is an example of Spanish Colonial Revival architecture.  Legend also has it that a ghost of a Spanish Soldier still guards the archway, unaware that he was killed by the misfire of his own musket.Before I arrived, I was kind of stressed.  Later that evening, I had to give a presentation for work. Plus, I had fifty important unread e-mails in my inbox. However, when I checked-in, all my stress soon vanished. Parking was readily available, the innkeeper had my room key and paperwork ready, I was offered a very lovely "free" glass of Pinot Noir and my suitcases were quickly brought to my room. My room was charming and cozy. The floors were made of wood, the bathroom was clean and modern, fresh orchids were on the dresser, the Wi-Fi signal was strong and the atmosphere was incredibly quiet. I detest noise pollution and I didn't hear a single sound except for that of the fan overhead. The room reminded me of guesthouses in Europe. I smelled and sensed "history" in the walls. Indeed, the history of Saint Augustine was with me. Later, I took a little stroll. The entire building was adorable and tranquil. The outdoor sitting area had a small garden filled with orchids. That evening, after my presentation and after hitting the local bars, I headed back to the Inn. I saw the innkeeper outside drinking a red wine and he invited my to join him. Together, we sat for thirty minutes at a black iron table overlooking the Lightner Museum talking about life, wine and the history of the city. It was pleasant. Even though a Spanish Soldier haunts the Old City House, I still slept very peacefully and unfortunately didn't see him. In the morning for breakfast, the very handsome cook and server (from France I think) brought out 2 courses with a plate at a time. The first breakfast was a lot of fruit, eggs, and waffles. The second breakfast was a savory enchilada. In sum, the Old City House Inn has sufficient parking, excellent food and service.  It is also pet friendly and it is right next to all the attractions. If I could suggest anything, it would be to have a newspaper outside the door of the guest-rooms in the morning.  I would have loved to eat breakfast and drink my coffee while reading the Wall Street Journal or New York Times. It would also be nice to have a small pool near the garden.I will definitely come back to this inn whenever I am in St. Augustine. Too many cities are littered with your average chain hotel without any charm or individuality. The charm and beauty of the Old City House Inn & Restaurant adds a lot of value to the city.This review is based upon my experiences at the bed and breakfast.  Although I have not had the opportunity to have dinner at the restaurant, the menu looks really good.After having bad experiences at several bed and breakfasts around the downtown St. Augustine area, we finally came across Old City Inn who fortunately had some last minute availability.  The location is perfect, tucked just behind the fancy Casa Monica hotel.  Walking out the door, you are a one minute walk from Flagler College, Bridge of Lions and some of the nicer bars and restaurants (JP Henleys!!). During the day the sightseeing trains frequently pass by, but I don't think they run at night because I have never had any noise issues.  Also being off the main roads there isn't too much noise to keep you up at night.The rooms are quite spacious and include a comfortable bed, tv, bathroom/shower.  We have stayed in three of the rooms, but generally prefer the Alcazar as it has a private entrance up the side of the building.  The rates are reasonable as well and they frequently run specials on their website such as stay 1 day get another free, 20% off, ect.  I think they also have last minute rates if you call up the night of. We have had some terrible breakfast at other establishments in the downtown area, but the breakfast at Old City inn had always been quite good.  And as the name would suggest, it is included in the price of your stay.  You can choose to sit inside or outside in the front or courtyard.  I believe the options consist of French toast, Belgium waffle, English breakfast, eggs Benedict, and southern Benedict, which has become my go to breakfast choice!  I have had most everything at some point in time, and while I'm not a huge breakfast person, everything has been really good. The food can sometimes take a longer than expected time to get out to you if there are several people dining.   Service has always been fair, and they check on you multiple times which is nice especially when sitting outside. If you are spending some time in St. Augustine, consider staying with Old City Inn.  With a great location, tasty breakfast, nice clean accommodations, and reasonable prices, you really cannot beat it'This is perhaps the most under rated restaurant the food belongs at a 5 star restaurant in Manhattan, Paris , Madrid or any place you can think of. Fabulous chef prepared food that can't be praised enough. Don't miss this place !!!!!We went during the afternoon when they had their small plates menu available. At 6 bucks a pop it was incredibly affordable for the quality. Everything tasted great ...the staff was very nice...and I wouldn't hesitate to come back any time!Really really wish we could have stayed longer than one night.    This was such a quaint and enjoyable inn.   The room was nice and the bed was comfortable.    The courtyards at the inn were very nice and lush.   We went to the restaurant area during the 5-6 wine and cheese plate time and the cheese plate was very good.   Good pours on the red wine.   Later went back for appetizers and my husband had a shrimp one that was very good.  I ordered another cheese plate like I had earlier and they did explain that they would have to charge which I totally expected, however it def wasn't worth the $17 charge for it.   The free one had better cheeses on it.   My mistake on not asking before ordering.   Other than that everything about this place was amazing.   Staff and ambiance was great!!!   Location was perfect.
review_content_40: When I stayed at this B&B in 2008, everything was 5-star.  Charming themed rooms, great rooftop patio, great location, historical story within, great price (too many steps, all rooms are upstairs so be a healthy stair-climber).  My breakfasts were memorable and 5-star at the restaurant.  I remember a fab fritatta.  Also had a great bananas foster.  Had great duck for a fine dinner.  Intimate, romantic restaurant.When I went back last week, simply for lunch, we found the menu limited and without "pizazz".  The desserts changed.  The blonde female appeared distracted. (Twice when we came through to check things out, no one was there, no bell, no one came.)  When you review the 5-star reviews they are years old.  This place currently seems understaffed and less interested in drawing a crowd.  (The town was bursting with crowds this week, this place was empty.)Please note this review is based on observation--we chose NOT to eat there based on the menu and lack of human connection.  Maybe next time.The location is fantastic.We really enjoyed our stay at the old city house inn. The staff was very nice and attentive. We stayed in the Ammidown room, very cozy and comfy bed.  The location is excellent, very close to everything in the historic district, only 1/2 a block off the beaten path so its a bit quieter.  They give options for breakfast which is a bonus and it tastes good too.I was here almost 10 years ago, but I always remember how awesome this place was.  Nice romantic atmosphere but not stuffy.  The food was SO delicious.  I can't wait to go back!No objection to the food, but it is truly WAY overpriced - for the brunch, at least.  Service and food were ok, simly worth nothing near what we paid for our meal.I love this place. We went here for the first time with another couple and ordered the sliders and lobster appetizers, followed by the filet, scallops, lamb and a grouper special.....wow! everything was prepared and presented perfectly. The scallops were so fresh and cooked just right, best I've ever had.We ended up eating there two more times in a week. It was great every time.The atmosphere and food are just right. It is never really crowded and the staff are very attentive.Great service. Quaint and quiet location. Nice drinks and the food was well prepared. I would recommend and will likely return with friends later in the season.We came here for breakfast and are so glad that we did. Nice service and really great food. We had the stuffed French toast and Southern Benedict and both were delicious. The setting is nice a little bit upscale but cozy.I share the same comment from a previous review-USE to be one of our favorites in st. Aug.We live in St. Augustine and feel that the improper way our situation by the general manager, Marty, was handled in a manor that is unheard of in the industry.Note-we have eaten at old city house well over 20 times and had good experiences but not on Saturday evening.  Ordered tuna appreciate as my meal and it was well done.  Moved it around on my plate to determine if any of it was medium rare.Sent it back and was asked if I would like another portion.  I stated no because you never know were the next piece had been.  Received my bill and was not removed.  Marty-the general manager, stated that i ate half the tuna and he offered to replace not remove from the bill.After carrying on with Marty on about his lack of wanting to make it right,  we left and will NEVER GO BACK!!!!!!  I have already expressed my displeasure with 30 friends and plan on making sure that no one has to deal with this type of attitude which is a shame because it was a nice place to eat.Very Wonderful!Service was nice (LOL, there were only 2 tables filled and 2 waiters, so we pretty much got good service!...altho had to wait to catch someones eye a couple of times to request something.The restaurant has a little bit of a Slavic or Eastern European/Polish hint to it (the balsamic vinagrette had poppyseeds) and I cannot recall the other 'hints' the Hubby mentioned. He is of this decent, and not only could we distinguish an accent in the food, but the waiters as well.Food was outstanding. We were staying Next door at Casa Monica, and had great food there also, but we so happy to have discovered this place via yelp before our visit, and had made a reservation ahead of time.I had a chicken breast which was kinf of like a cordon bleu, altho it was stuffed with only mozz and basil, and it had the most WONDERFUL bechamel sauce on it, and the ''fried' outer layer was so thin and delicate, the little tiny crunch it gave was a delight in my mouth!We loved the house salad dressings (the salad was utilitarian in nature), but with the dressings, which they suggest MIXING....the poppyseed balsamic vinagratte and a creamy garlic dressing. each was fabo in itself, but OMG when u DID mix them, they rounded right out and were so smooth and delicious! I was wiping my plate with my very HARD and CRUNCH Ciabatta bread at the end....ok, will finsih this later, mouth is watering.....need a snack! WIsh I was back at this restaurant!Recently travelled to St. Augustine for a little romantic getaway.  My wife and I have become quite the world travellers and we have been blessed to have had experience with many 5-star accomodations (e.g. Four Seasons, Thailand).  Because of this, we find that even when a restaurant is very good, it always seems to pale against our more luxiourious experiences.  Not so with this darling little find.The Old City House Restaurant really made an impression on us.  Tucked away within an inn near the city's center, this restaurant is pleasantly appointed with a very high attention to detail.  The staff was genuine, hospitable and down-to-earth.  We felt very welcome here.Now to the food.  Everything was superbly prepared.  That included the usually forgettable house salad.  The main courses were the real show (as they should be).  I had medium-rare ostrich which was done to perfection.  I've had ostrich several times, but this was a true winner.  My wife ordered the surf and turf.  The filet was cooked to an exact medium rare and crusty on the outside.  That type of accuracy in preparation typically only happens in the best steak restaurants.  The seafood cake was 95% crab and very little filler.  Excellent in every domain.The desert du jour was hot bread pudding with white raisins, chocolate sauce and vanilla ice cream.  Just like the understated yet well created interior of the restaurant, the desert wowed us with the fact it was made with a lot of love.Bravo!  For such a small restaurant to have achieved this type of balance while not getting a big ego over it is something to be congratulated.  We would absolutely return, if nothing more than to enjoy your hospitality.I hate to say I disagree but I disagree. The only thing I enjoyed about this experience was the cheesecake. I ordered the sea food crepe and I know this might not make sense, but it was very seafoody. What I mean is when sea food tastes good it taste like shrimp, scallops, etc. This just tasted like sea water. It wasn't great. The waitress blamed me saying "you ordered seafood". Then when I ordered cheesecake she said that the real reason I didn't eat is because I wanted cheesecake. Um ya she lost major points on that one.  My boyfriend the feat bacon burger and it was really good. Maybe of k ha ordered the burger the star count would have been higher, but based on rudeness and grossness I will have to give it 2 stars. Ps we went because it emphasized south African influence. My boyfriend is south African and the pictures on wall were only south African influence we saw. The other waitresses seemed nice wish we enjoyed this more, but alas we won't be visiting this place again soon.Upon arriving in St. Augustine my wife and I were not impressed with much the city had to offer.  We had booked a week long trip at a local hotel which was beautiful, but noticed that the city was more of a B&B kind of city. We stumbled through the city and found the Old City House Inn & Restaurant...This was the highlight of our trip! the building is beautiful! it turns out it was Henry Flagers stable house for his horses  many years ago.  the rooms were perfect! we chose the Augusitn (i believe is the name) it was perfect ! 4 post bed awesome layout! .  Like i said we werent too impressed with the food in the city but we decieded to try their restaurant out. The food was fantastic... I had a pan roasted grouper encrusted with jumbo lump crab meat with a garlic herb sauce, my wife ( a huge curry fan ) had their thai curry she said was the most authentic she has every had, my food had to be the best Ive had in years.  we will return again

review_content: Am I a hotel snob....yes. Lol.  So with that being said.  This hotel was just ok.  It's a little creepy on the inside.  I've never seen a hotel with such a setup. It looks as if it could have possible previously been a outdoor hotel that they decided to enclose.  It was just very different.  The room itself was fine.  My bed was comfy, room was clean.  But I noticed a few stains on my towels when I held them up to the light. Considering the large crowd they had during my overnight stay, the breakfast area was fully stocked and I was able to grab what I needed very quickly.  Great location for the Diva Run event I attended.  If you are going to the amphitheater, again this hotel is in a great location.  The venue definitely needs an upgrade, but overall not a bad place.I pretty much only stay at Hilton chain hotels as I am a Hilton Honors member with diamond elite status.  This is by far the worst Hampton I have stayed at, and I've stayed at a lot of them.First, it badly needs updating.  The room decor was hideous.  Second, it's not exactly on the beach but pretty far off set from it. Third, the room did not seem clean, we found a spent coke bottle along the baseboard of the bed.  Housekeeping...look under the bed skirts.I booked an ocean front room with a deck.  I checked in and got stuck on second floor (room 207) where we could barely see the water over the dunes.  I used my points for the room and believe I got stuck on a lower level and sub par room because of it.  I was fed some bs about all the upper floors were already reserved when I was checking in early and could not pick any particular room on line in advance.This is a very nice Hampton Inn right on the beach beautiful facilities dining located right across the street I accidentally left my phone charger there and they are going to send it to me how's that for service. The breakfast on Sunday was good, the staff friendly and accommodating .smell of room unbelievably awful-cross between dirty socks and wet dog.  carpet and most of the room shabby and in need of updating.  breakfast also in need of an overhaul.  i've been to numerous hamptons and eaten in their breakfast rooms.  this one is on the small side in room space, and the food offered is messy in presentation and low quality.  few if any whole grain bread choices.the only reason for a second star is because of the ocean view and location.  this stay we got the fourth floor rather than the second floor last time.  but  the same beach is publicly accessible about a half mile down the road with free parking.  there are other hotels just across the street away from the ocean, thus no ocean view.fyi-there is a new Embassy suites resorts going in just down the road also tho no building started.  ocean front/view.would not return here unless knew it has been renovated.Well, this is not so good.I'm a Hampton Inn regular (a HHonors Diamond), and have stayed in dozens of them throughout the country.  This is a poor one.  Here's my rundown:GOOD:- Location is great.- Private beach is big and right out back.BAD:- It needs a full renovation.  It is old.  The hallways are dark.  The carpet is worn.- The breakfast area is TINY.  Read more below.- The parking lot is too small and gets completely full every night.Breakfast is a disaster.  It's tiny.  There are about six 4-top tables, maybe six 2-tops, and that's it.  It was totally slammed every morning.  The line for food was 15 people deep, and blocked the coffee.  Trashcans were overflowing.  Tables were filthy.  It's just woefully inadequate for the number of rooms and guests at this property.So I'm disappointed.  Hampton is usually very consistent, and I trust them.  They let me down at this site.  It is just not up to the standards of Hampton Inn.Good value, GREAT location, and a very personable front desk staff!  Clean rooms, accommodating and comfortable.  We would definitely stay here again!  Our room was on the first floor with a patio that was connected right to the pool/hot tub area!  One wish is that there was a gate on our patio fence so we could get to the pool without having to leave the room.  You couldn't possibly ask for easier access to the huge beach.  Also a great playground that my 4 year old LOVED!The view from our balcony was great, the friendless of the staff even better. However the bed sucked I would rather have slept in the chair.  The access to beach and breakfast was ideal and better than expected they must get better beds and larger TVs to make this an ideal place.We stayed here in October of2014. Room are clean, plenty of space. A very close walk to beach. Free wifi need a car to go to  st. Augustine old town. The breakfast was a 4 out of 5 eggs, beacon, bread, fruit, waffles great coffee in the room as well as at breakfast. Highly recommend.Hilton Garden Inn was sold out so we tried the Hampton. Beautiful hotel by the beach. Clean & modern rooms with patios. Complimentary breakfast from 6-10, complimentary cookies at 7pm, and complimentary coffee/tea/hour cocoa all the time. Friendly staff. Decent gym with updated equipment. Pool and hot tub located inside.The hotel is pretty standard for a Hampton Inn, being in the "budget" tier of Hilton properties.  The room was clean, the bed was comfortable, and the A/C worked great.What sets this place apart though, is the whirpool tub rooms and the proximity to the beach.I opted to splurge a bit and get a room with a whirlpool tub.  Separate from the bathroom and shower, this tub sits out in the open right next to the bed [see photos]. Let's just say... it's a good room for couples.Each water-facing room has a little patio in the back with a couple of chairs, should you want to catch a sunrise or just hang out [see photo].Through the lobby to the back of the hotel is a door that lets you out to the pool and the boardwalk to the private beach entrance.  It's nice. I walked out there in the morning, stopped about halfway down the boardwalk to watch a few wild rabbits hopping around and nibbling in a grassy area, and continued out to the beach entrance.A couple of minor annoyances: The parking lot is too small to handle a full hotel.  We got back late one night and I had to park under the overhang by the front door.  When I woke up in the morning, I went out and there was at least four cars under that overhang.  The room that they have the free breakfast items in is also too small for a crowd.  It was a nightmare trying to get through all of the people that were waiting in line, or just milling about aimlessly.  No tables were available so we had to go out into the pool area to eat.  Also, they ran out of little cream cheese tubs for the bagels and when they put more out, they were frozen solid.Still not a bad place.  We'll come back as the opportunity arises.I love being a Hilton Honors member. Seriously one of the best decisions I ever made and I am not joking. American Express/Hilton Honors - watch your points GROW. Plus your incentive to frequent Hilton properties when you travel. Game on. So here we are...best girlfriends weekend, St Augustine Florida and we found a Hampton Inn on A1A on the beach for a very reasonable cost. $179 a night. Bit much for a Hampton but it's on the beach. You walk out and you are on the beach. The staff is AWESOME. Front desk, housekeeping. Just amazing. You get the same consistent service anytime of the hour or day.  When you pull up the property is very Florida. By that I mean screaming pink building. Plus, the property is older. It's not NEW so you have to manage your expectations a bit compared to other Hampton Inn properties.  We had our own balcony.  Our own micro, fridge. The shower pressure was awesome. The pool was perfect. There is a whirl pool as well.  The fitness center looked very small but again, who wants to go there when you roll outside of your bed and you're at the beach? And I LOVE to workout! :) Would totally go back in an instant. One of the best hotel experiences ever.First off, staff was great!!! Only reason it got a 3 star...Stayed in room 316, just for a nightAsked for a double queen bed suite.Call me crazy but those must of been FULL size... They felt tiny!!!! I have stayed at Hampton inns through out the US and their quality standard for this room was not the same. ( I travel very regular due to my job although this was a family trip which is what made it even more disappointing, after my daughter had found a room at a holiday inn of some sorts in the area I told her NOWAY!!! After seeing the Hampton inn, I said to her that ( Hampton inns had better rooms) BOY DID I FEEL STUPID!!!I regret to say I was disappointed in the room. AGAIN, the person on staff (Shannon) was super polite and helpful. I have no complaints on the customer serviceWe didn't eat in the breakfast area due to time restraints but it did seem tiny for the amount of rooms on the property. Probably won't be staying there again.Thanks,Just checked in. Nice front desk person. Got to room. Tv doesn't work. They are trying to fix it and won't let me change rooms yet. Lumbar pillows on the bed don't look like they've been washed for a month or more. We'll see how it goes from here...OK.  Spent the night.  Loud people in the hallway.  Not my kind of property.  Nuff said.I love this hotel & the staff. They have the best general manager EVER, Kristin! This is our 2nd trip & they welcomed us back like family. They are so very accommodating & ready to offer suggestions & pointers on what to do & how to make the most of our visit. We have never had better customer service at any hotel ever!!!!!Friendly Staff. Amber at the front desk was so lovely and had a very cute southern accent! Stephanie from Breakfast was a nice lady too. A man asked her why she got a big smile on her face.
