Staff was very nice, helpful and welcoming.  Had a room upgrade to a large one bedroom suite - wish we were staying longer!  Room was large, well maintained and very clean.  I was able to get a very good rate online which made it even better.  Next time in Saint A, we'd definitely want to stay here!It's just a really cool place to stay. The hotel has a lot of history and  it is very different from any hotel we've stayed at before. Centrally located makes for an easy walk to everything.  Food was great. Service was great. It's a tad pricey but for a special occasion it's worth it.It really is grand and gorgeous. Upon laying your eyes on this gem, it is confirmed that this is a majestic 1888 landmark hotel. I adore St. Augustine and try to visit at least one a year. It's historic, gorgeous, relaxing and just a lovely place to spend the day or weekend.  I stayed at this lovely castle turned hotel earlier this year and it was delightful. The beauty of this place it just breathtaking. Part of the Kessler collection, this hotel delivers just like the rest of them; a true classy, swanky and upscale brand. Rich colors, lovely scents and just so much character with the decor. Lynsay at front desk was super nice! We asked for some suggestions on must eats and dos and she popped out a map and showed us all over. Very welcoming. The room was lovely and comfortable. This was a very brief stay due to some scheduling conflicts and I am very disappointed we did not get to check out more of the hotel and the pool. It is very pricey so I would suggest booking for a certain occasion and make sure you have time to sit back, relax and enjoy. One small downside was the valet. We rolled up in a Jeep and they did not inform us that the cars would be staying outside overnight and they did not allow us to secure the Jeep correctly so that was a bit frustrating. We would have appreciated a heads up. Good thing it did not rain that night!Stumbled upon this wonderful hotel through Luxury Link- and what a great find!! Located right in the middle of town it was easy to navigate to little pubs/bars. Everywhere we chose to go was walking distance. Wonderful!!And for the hotel...we upgraded to the Kessler suite which was amazing!! More space then we knew what to do with. Only downfall was no big tub in the master bedroom- which you would expect in their largest suite. Staff was curious and accommodating. It was very clean! Hotel restaurant was very good, and the lounge bar was great! Best pizza I've ever had... Good love music... Great drinks! Would definitely go here again!
review_content_60: Why hello there Casa Monica Hotel. You sure are looking nice today and everyday for that matter. Casa Monica Hotel is a very classy hotel in which I wouldn't mind spending the night. I am sure the hotel is expensive based on its appearance and "fancy" style. However, I know that if you search for a good deal one can be found. In fact, some friends of mine were able to get a good discount and spend about $90 for the night back in December...deals are available! I arrived at the hotel after a wedding at the Lightner Museum for some drinks with other guests. The lobby area was very inviting and the concierge was friendly. He directed us to the bar area in which we were able to find a table (a few tables) for all of us. We looked over the drink menu and were able to order everything from beer, wine, cosmos, and martinis. It was a simple menu with simple options. I wasn't in the mood to be making a decision so when I saw they had martinis I was ready for one. The service was great and the bartender was doing a great job keeping the drinks coming! I will say that drinks cost $10+ depending on what you get so be prepared to  spend your money when you arrive. The drinks were worth it though. I felt classy drinking in the Casa Monica.Top quality brunch with a raw bar, omelette station and the works.Tempted to give it 3 stars, but just couldn't. A 3.5* or better hotel should not have tube TVs. But the Casa Monica does - good ol' 1990s-era tube TVs in every room. Considering what the Casa Monica charges, there is really no excuse for clunky old TVs. The reason must be no competition in the historic district of St. Augustine.I did appreciate the cafe downstairs with the cool street view and good coffee drinks. But the pool area is basically an internal courtyard with no natural view, and after only 15 mins of working on my MacBook poolside, tiny mite-like bugs started to crawl out from under the pool furniture onto my computer case. Ewwww. I packed up and went back to my room.Casa Monica may be the best of St. Augustine, but that isn't saying much at all. Even a lower-tier 3* property in Las Vegas like the Excalibur or virtually any Hampton Inn / Hyatt Place / Courtyard by Marriott blows the doors off of Casa Monica, room feature to room feature.Be aware that there is no true grocery store, convenience store or chain-pharmacy within walking distance of this hotel. Nor is there any store that you would find in a mall (e.g. Ralph Lauren, Lacoste, The Gap) within walking distance, so don't forget any snacks or socks before you decide to coop up at the Casa Monica. Room Service shuts down at 11PM, too. What does one do in historic St. Augustine? A religious fasting retreat would be a good fit.This and only this is the finest hotel in St Augustine. I've attended many a meeting here and I have no material complaints what-so-ever.  * The meeting room is classy and private.  * The service is perfecto. * The restaurant (yes, a restaurant in a hotel! *faint*) is really outstanding. * The valet parking is affordable and convenient.The rooms are historic. If you are expecting stainless steel, granite countertops, ipod docking stations, and flat panel TV's, this isn't the right spot for you.This is one of my favorite hotels to stay in, as often as I can.  I only wish my travels took me to St. Augustine more often so that I could stay more frequently.I read some of the other reviews of the Casa Monica on Yelp; thankfully, I've never experienced those issues during my several stays there.  The front desk staff is always very pleasant, welcoming and professional; I often need assistance with several bags and the bell staff are also really nice, professional, and can help with local dining recommendations, too.The hotel rooms themselves are well-appointed, with a vintage flair; red velvet headboards, for instance.  The rooms are very quiet, even when there is a lot of street noise from traffic (most of the time, my stays involved a street-facing room).  Another prime reason to stay at the Casa Monica is its location; it is right in the heart of the city.  So many of the destinations that you come to St. Augustine for are within easy walking distance from the hotel.I also have to really commend the housekeeping staff at the hotel; they go to great pains to keep the rooms exceptionally clean, and each one will greet you pleasantly when you see them in the halls, unlike many places you may visit.  On my last visit, the housekeeper even left a nice thank you note, for spending time at her hotel, something I thought was a nice touch.I stayed here for a work conference. We pulled up to the valet. The valet greeted us warmly. Parking is $17/day plus tax. The valet area was clean and there was even an old-timey car in the area that really set the tone.We walked into the lobby and we were immediately transpoted to old Spain. There was beautifully carved dark furniture everywhere. Dark reds, mosaics, bronze and the lobby smelled amazing. We proceeded to check-in. The process was fairly quick. The front desk person seemed rushed and wasn't overly friendly, but I got my room keys and set off to find my room.The elevators were small, but fast. I got to the fourth floor and found my room. The hallways and lobby areas were all clean.I found my room. It was fairly small, but this is a historic hotel. That said, it really stands out compared to other old hotels. He room was  modernized with updated drywall, light fixtures, and a coffee machine. The only negative in the room was the TV. It was a big box TV and the quality wasn't very good - but who goes to St. Augustine to watch TV anyway?The bed had a huge red tufted velvet headboard. The room had tons of dark wood furniture. The king sized bed was comfortable and cozy. The sheets were soft and clean.The bathroom was very clean and spacious. The  bathroom counter had plenty of space for all of your toiletries and then some! We so used the Flagler Ballroom for our work meetings. I would love to come back and host a party there. The location is gorgeous. There are beautiful paintings, dark woods, beautiful Moorish light fixtures. Overall, a very beautiful space. If you're coming to St. Augustine, you have to stay here. This hotel is  the true essence of  the old city.I'll start with the great things about this hotel.  It's a gorgeous and authentic building with attractive furnishing and extremely courteous staff.  The location is also perfect for its proximity to local attractions.  They also host weddings and other events, making the hotel a natural choice if you're attending such an event.All that being said, I didn't find the hotel a great value.  In particular I felt nickel-and-dimed by all the extra charges.  My nightly $339/nt + tax rate seemed high enough as it is, but they also charged $24/nt for parking and $9.95 per device per day for Internet access.  Don't make the mistake of using the hotel room phone, as a 10 minute domestic long distance call costs $43.  Even local calls are $1 each.I was also disappointed by their 11AM checkout policy.  I requested a 1pm checkout, but the best they would offer was Noon.  I'm pretty accustomed to checking out much later from rooms which cost much less.Our room was fine, but not what I would expect for the high price.  We only had a tiny window and it overlooked a rooftop.  A plaque by the window explained that the tiny window was a special historical feature of the hotel.  The gym was small but at least adequate and they didn't try to charge extra for using it.The Casa Monica is gorgeous. It's fancy and expensive.  But you know that already.We stayed at the Casa Monica for one main reason: We were getting married in the courtyard of the Lightner Museum right next door, and I wanted a good place with a big room where my wife could get ready with her bridesmaids and makeup person and hair person and various mothers and friends and not feel too terribly cramped.And so we ended up in Room 504, a large beautifully decorated room with a big bathroom and a four-poster bed with the white sheets hanging down curtain-style around the outside edges. Three large windows let the perfect amount of natural light in, and a Bose clock radio was softly playing jazz as we walked in.My friend's room, where the groomsmen got ready, was actually a two-story room with a small living area downstairs (a couple of nice couches, a chair, a TV, and a bar area) and a bedroom upstairs separated by an iron staircase.  It had a bathroom on each floor. Amazing.The service (in any respect) was generally amazing.  When they found out about the fact that we were there for the wedding, they sent someone to each of the two rooms with wine glasses so we didn't have to keep drinking out of plastic cups.  The ladies got a visit from a gentlemen with a number of chairs for the room so everyone would have a place to sit.The valet parking system.... maybe could have used a little work, at least on the first day we were there.  I had to go back for my checkbook which I had left in the car. Rather than allow me to just go to the car and get it, I had to wait for a valet to bring the car around.  Since another wedding was about to take place, there was a rush of cars and it took me over half an hour to get my car.  And then 10 seconds later I handed them the keys back and they had to go re-park it.Overall, if I had money burning a hole in my pocket I wouldn't hesitate to stay here again.This hotel is A-Ok. There are many things about it that make it 5 stars and just as many making it a single star destination. The hotel is elegant, imposing, and bold. Beautifully situated in the heart of the downtown area. Location is among the best. Another pro is that there is a hotel bar and fun, live jazz music in the lobby at night. Hotel bars seem to be rare in St. Augustine. Great for meeting up before dinner.The hotel nickels and dimes a lot (e.g. $10 for wifi and $25 PER DAY valet parking). Finding an overnight parking spot downtown can be tricky so it's worth it, plus the valet staff is super attentive and quick. However, at the price you're paying for the hotel, it's simply insulting to charge guests for valet. The difference between great hotels and ordinary ones are often in the details. On the surface this hotel is 5-stars; take a look closer and you'll find it's lacking... here are some examples:- housekeeping forgot to put shampoo and conditioner in the room. I had to wash my hair with soap because it was too late. Already stepped in the shower and had to get ready.- the toilet continued to run and the seat kept shifting to the side. gross.- the pool was closed from 2pm-10pm for an event. we drove an hour to get to the hotel with the kids and they were so disappointed. the hotel did offer an alternative but it was 15 min away... a heads up would have been appreciated via mass email. - the pool is miniature! most hotels in the area do not have pools so it's better to have one than not. Just keep in mind that it's more like a 3ft deep plunge pool to cool off... not a "swimming" pool.- our family stayed in one of the suites. it smelled like mildew. glad it wasn't our room. i would have imagined that the suites would be nicer.The price is for location, very friendly staff, and an overall nice hotel. Next time I'll book sooner and stay at a B&B or the Hilton (which are around the same price).Very pretty hotel, lovely rooms, bottle of house wine & coffee maker in room, super clean, fluffy bathrobes, in-room safe, but wish the other guests could have used their "inside" voices at 2 am...continuing until after 3 am despite calls to the desk to intervene...doors into hallway need more insulation! Gold and platinum Marriott reward members get free Internet.Awesome! Stayed this past weekend and enjoyed white glove treatment for a Cinco De Mayo getaway with my fiance.  Very clean and comfortable room, friendly staff and high attention to detail.If you're looking for a great value for your dollar, I would recommend checking out the Casa.  Also, we had dinner at the 95 Cordova Chop House in the hotel and it was as good or better then the big name steakhouses .This is a great old-guard hotel in downtown St. Augustine.  The moorish decorations may not work for everybody, but I thought they worked.  Rooms were well laid-out, and the staff was helpful.  Parking was a pain, and valet parking was pretty expensive, but that was the primary drawback.  It's a landmark for a reason.Eeeck.... My fiance and I chose this location  banking on Kessler's reputation. We normally choose the Waldorf when we are looking to escape monotony.  We booked a premium room, when booking there was a picture of a soaking tub which I was really looking forward too. Upon arrival our room had a standup shower. This may have been my own mistake but still disappointing. We dined at the Cordova for dinner the first night, we were looking forward to a high end steak house. I ordered the filet mignon well done, being pregnant that was my only option. I normally choose a medium well. It took a very long time to actually get our meal, when I got it it was rare! Lol aka still moo-ing! I politely asked our server, who was as kind as can be to send it back for well done. My fiance had the lobster tail risotto dish which was wonderful. After getting my meal for a second time I cut into my steak and again in was rare. Being annoyed if asked to speak with the manager I explained that this was the second time sending my food back to the kitchen. He said " would you like to give us a third try" shocked that he was not remotely embarrassed, I said no and we went back to our room. Being our first night we were excited to jump into bed and enjoy a movie, the beds were not comfortable. The beds are of the same quality as the beat western or perhaps slightly inferior. I was again disappointed. The location was prime, my fiance enjoyed st. Augustine and all the shopping it had to offer. We decided to head back to our room for some lunch. We ordered in, when reviving our lunch we discovered that the kitchen had prepared a bacon avocado burger, forgetting to include the bacon or the avocado. Yet again another disappointment.We also realized upon arriving the spa advertised was not open for business yet.Synopsis:Unfortunately this hotel was very disappointing.  This beautifully decorated, opulent structure has no real place in the 4-5 star hotel chain selection. The location is prime, however it lacks  great service and luxuries amenities. I think they may need some reorganization in their management system. I would not expect this type of experience for $400 a night. I will not be visiting the hotel or the Kessler brand for our vacations.If you enjoy luxurious relaxing vacations I urge you not to have high hopes for Casa Monica.Gorgeous property, great staff. Ask about the ghosts...they say there aren't any, but I disagree! Fun stuff!The setting was nice, music was engaging acoustic classical guitarDuo, service was adequate, however the food quality was disappointing.Shrimp rubbery, oysters deteriorating, prime rib over cooked, the food layout confusing. The level of food quality and presentation is not in keeping with their Golden spoon award-status.We have been to St. Augustine many times over the years and had always wondered what it would be like to stay here. This time we did.  It is a very opulent hotel - some would say over the top -that has a lot of history behind it.  I won't bore you with the history at the moment.  Thing is though they have restored it to what it was originally meant to be, so yes, it is over the top and lush.Its not a cheap hotel, it is considered the best in St. Augustine.  There is no other parking or parking option other than valet - for $20, so keep that in mind.The room was large, very nice and although I have been in nicer rooms at lesser hotels here you are paying for the whole package.  You feel like royalty when you stay here.The front desk staff was beyond stellar, however we were promised a bell hop and never got one.  Since we have no problem carrying our own bags it wasn't a big deal.All in all you stay here for an experience, for the history, and the location cannot be beat. Its old but updated, beautiful and historic.This historical and unique hotel stands alone as a true gem in the heart of the historic district in St. Augustine. Just a few steps away from St. George street, its location is privileged. During our stay here we did not have to move the car at all, everything is reasonably close and the walks are really enjoyable. The Lobby is quite unique and we found the service to be fantastic. The rooms are quite comfortable, clean and modern despite the fact that hotel is quite a few years old. There is a myth out there about this hotel being haunted.... all I can say is- it may be haunted ....or maybe not....stay and find out for yourself, either way, you will not be disappointed.Overall the hotel is nice, lots of charm but theres lots of room for improvement especially for the "Ritz" price at nearly $300.00 per night.  The pool and bar drinks are also double the price of the surrounding bars. The Room Service same song different verse. The staff was really nice and professional. I would be very happy staying here if I was paying the price of a 3 Star hotel. Great location, walking distance to everything.My dear if only there was coffee available at five am there could be five stars!! Charming location and period furniture; visitors will be charmed. Valet n front desk exceptional n professional. We had a cocktail mixed just to taste by our able bartender. 4th floor room nice view n quiet. Walk straight down cordoba past Flagler uni to enjoy a stroll through pretty lanes jam packed w tasteful and absurd commerce! Kitschy and fun. Location seems perfect for this n you won't be disappointed. The coffee maker in the room sufficed but woke up partner trying to make a five o'clock cup. Bring room snack mine was a fiber one bar left in car... No vending machines or snacks at front desk to buy. Nada!  Starbucks yu were sooo close but not awake like I was......This is a beautiful hotel as far as the lobby and bar are concerned; however, for $400/night, it was definitely not worth the money.  I will stay at a B&B next visit.
review_content_80: Not a great experience After being awakened at 4:26 am by naked people running around the pool areaMaking a lot of noise . I and my wife could not go back to sleep . Worst night ever . I found out later that it happens there all the time ( the college students break in often)I called the general manager and left a message . Four days later stillNo call back . Very bad manners . All we got offered was a cup of coffee and water . Didn't  Even get the wine that supposedly comes with the room .The general manager should be fired . I hate to be negative  but we paid full price for this room and it absolutely was not worth it. Sorry but the manager not retuning a call is not good practice or good etiquette .This is a beautiful hotel in the middle of historic St. Augustine!  We the only thing it doesn't have is a view!  We only stayed one night on our way to Southern Florida so for us it was perfect!  We were able to walk around the town and the front desk recommended a great breakfast place with a great view! (Mary's/Harbor View Cafe) Our room was really spacious, comfortable & clean!  Would definitely stay there again!Casa Monica is the best hotel in St. Augustine. While $250 may be pricey in Florida coming from San Francisco that seemed reasonable for the best hotel in town. I loved the design of hotel and Spanish/Moorish architecture. I love the lobby and pool are and spent many nights by the hotel bar with friends. It is located conveniently near major attractions. I would definitely recommend it.The Casa Monica was perfect for our anniversary vacation.  We booked through the site (taking advantage of the FL resident deal) for cheaper than any "deal" sites.  The hotel is beautiful and truly felt like we were in another time completely.   The room was larger than expected and the staff was extremely friendly and helpful.  Because it was our anniversary, champagne was delivered to our room upon arrival.  The hotel was also within walking distance of everything we visited in St. Augustine.  Overall, we had a wonderful experience and will definitely be back!Stayed here for 2 nights in honor of my mother's 50th birthday.  Hotel staff is excellent. They treat you with upmost respect. Valet services were great, they unload and load your luggage and bring it up to your room. Valet parking is $24 per night but the alternative is parking on street with the coin meters. Valet services were worth the fee and you can call for your car from the room before coming down. Hotel lobby is luxurious and has an art gallery to walk through. Small cafe is also available with Starbucks beverages. We stayed 4 in a regular room with 2 queens beds and it was very comfortable with a big bathroom. Will definitely book here again.For such an expensive and "upscale" hotel I expected better.  It was over-priced and I was very underwhelmed.  The water pressure in the shower was almost non-existent and when I called the front desk about it I was basically told to just deal with it.  The only parking available is valet and they charge $22 per vehicle per day.  If you need a fridge you have to pay extra for that too.  The pool is okay for wading as it is only 3 1/2 feet deep.  I really had high hopes for this place and was let down.  After a long day of exploring the city and swimming we came back to our room to a tv that is from the 1990s and a remote that did not work.  I was not impressed at all by this hotel and it goes to show that you do not always get what you pay for.Please do not think that I am cheap, we spent $1k staying here for 4 days and 3 nights.  I have spent much more than that at other hotels and have had the "wow" factor.  On my next trip to St. Augustine I may just elect to stay at a B & B or better yet I will just stay at the Hilton in Jacksonville and drive down.First let me say Casa Monica is quite a beautiful property. Every attention to detail was met when they renovated it and turned it into a Kessler Property. I was very pleased with the aesthetics and cleanliness when we stayed there. St. Augustine is a nice little gem of a city and over the years, I only stayed at Bed & Breakfasts. The mainstay that I always went to looked like it changed hands and wasn't as nice so for the first time, I tried for a larger hotel. I was impressed with the property overall however you paid for it. I did feel that the property was quite pricey. It was however St. Patrick's weekend as well as Bikeweek in Daytona with a lot of bikers spilling over there so that may have inflated the prices for the weekend. While it was too cold to use the pool, I fell in love with the area they created. Beautifully decorated, nice cabanas, bar service and very quiet out there. We ate at the restaurant one evening. It was a great meal, wonderful service from a server we had a lot in common with and a nice vibe, but it was really expensive. We spent around $200 or more and to me, it wasn't at that caliber. I don't mind paying for an incredible experience but it wasn't worth that in my opinion. The lobby bar however provided an incredible experience. We had artful cocktails and saw an incredibly talented husband and wife jazz duo playing flamenco jazz. They were such a treat for us. That definitely helped our experience. Would I stay there again? Yes.. but I would look for hotel promotions. Would I eat at the restaurant again? Probably not.I stay in hotels often and am always disappointed in something -- how housekeeping overlooks the little details, how the AC doesn't quite work, how loud the hallways are, how poorly the room is maintained, how worn the furnishings are, how the staff just doesn't quite seem to care.I now know that I DO NOT HAVE UNREASONABLE EXPECTATIONS, as Casa Monica   doesn't miss a single detail.  From the perfectly beautiful Spanish-style furnishings that were carefully dusted and polished, to the fact that they were appropriately sized for the room, to the lovely hand-written note left by housekeeping in appreciation of being left a tip -- Casa Monica will be the property by which I judge all others in the future.The staff at the front desk was always efficient, cheerful and helpful.  The staff in the restaurant and bar were equally impressive.  The restaurant does a wonderful job with breakfast and dinner, though I do have to say that the seating is rather uncomfortable.  The only other thing I have to zing them on is the lack of appropriate staffing in the StarBuck's on the premises, but I don't know if that falls under Casa Monica or Starbuck's themselves.  Being able to handle only one order at a time, the girl never even acknowledged the rest of the people patiently standing in line.  I just wanted to purchase a bottle of water, but she wouldn't ring me up while she already had her gloves off (from preparing food) ahead of anyone else who was ordering coffee or food she had to prepare.Our stay was provided by friends, but I asked at the desk how much the rooms are and was astounded to find out they were under $200/night. I hope to visit all Kessler properties in the future.  (We stayed the first week of April, 2013 and experienced nothing like the reviewer who stayed the prior month.)I stayed at the hotel - I did not eat in the restaurants or drink at the bar (shocker - I know). I love the look of this place and like other Kessler properties - they pick a theme and run with it. This place is supposed to be Moorish Glamorous as it would have been in its hay day at the turn of the century. It is a little bit like a shiny version of Disney's Tower of Terror hotel and the overall look works - consistent and stunning with attention to detail - especially in the lobby. Even the mirrors are ornate and in theme. The place just feels expensive and at the prices they charge per night (we paid $199 for a standard double) - you want it to be a little fancy. It is an older renovation - place went from hotel (late 1800s) to court offices, to vacant - to Kessler boutique hotel (renovated in the late 90s). I don't think there have been many upgrades since the original renovation - there are big old tube TVs in the room (I could care less), old phones, some dated fixtures, etc. Our room was not huge, but was very cozy and nice with a dark feel and plenty of storage. Typical of more expensive hotels - they nickle and dime every amenity because they assume it is going on some expense report. They had $5 bottles of Evian waiting for us and wanted to charge $11/day for Internet access (by the way - it is free in the coffee shop downstairs). I hate that - at the Marriott Fairfield Inn (Kessler is also a Marriott property) - it is a cheaper place to stay, just as clean, with free Internet and free breakfast, as a comparison. They also give you a cookie. I do not like the trend in more expensive hotels charging for more things - I called the Marriott customer service line (I am a rewards member) and managed to get my free Internet - turns out they have a password and user name at the ready for anyone who complains. Irritating. Also, be warned - it is $22/day to park, but I am OK with this as parking in St. Augustine is a commodity. The pool space is beautiful, rooms are elegant, needs some updating. Hate the nickle and dime stuff.Yesterday, I was in the bar area with a wedding party. My friend and I were trying to order food. Nobody came up to our table so I decided to walk up to the bar. I got the young male bartenders attention and politely asked if I could place an order or have someone sent to our table whenever he gets a chance (because I could see they were busy and overwhelmed). He then rolled his eyes at me and said he'd get to me when he could. A stranger next to me who saw the man roll his eyes at me, said out loud "well that was extremely rude of him". But I still continued to wait by the bar to order food because I was starving. He began taking everyone else's order around me except for mine, even though I was there before half the people at the bar. A man sitting at the bar next to me had seen how long I had been waiting and he flagged down the bartender to tell him to take my order. His response was again an even bigger eye roll and he rudely said he'd "get to me when he could". Needless to say, he was one of the rudest people I have ever met. I wish I got his name. I ended up going somewhere else.Lovely hotel, great service, central location.  Not cheap but the beds are super comfortable. Attentive staff. Downside - expensive valet parking and you have to pay for wifi in the rooms and it's not particularly high speed.  The hotel restaurant is beautiful and the food is quite good.The best hotel in St Augustine! Yes the parking is $22 per night and it isn't cheap but the service is 5 star and if your platinum with Marriott they will find every opportunity to upgrade you. We have stayed twice and both times we got a suite for the price of a standard room. The pool isn't good I will say that but the furniture and style make up for it. The only place I will stay when in St Augustine.The ONLY reason I didn't give it 5 stars was the window!  Lindsay (I'm so sorry I think I am spelling your first name incorrectly, please forgive me!)  Made us feel very welcome and was the BEST first impression!  Fantastic.A beautiful (expensive) hotel, all first class, THANKS!Our stay at Casa Monica was luxurious and relaxing.  I wouldn't stay anywhere else in St. Augustine!  The beds are very comfortable, the showers are great and the service is top of the line.Lucky to stay her for our annual company meeting. I have been to St. Aug many times but never stayed here. Would highly recommend for the accomodations, location and ambiance. Staff was fantastic and all the meals we had in the hotel were great. Probably the one of the best venues we have had for our annual meeting.  Price is in line with what we expect in a big city but this is a better hotel and in my opinion a better deal for the money.We just had our wedding reception here and can't say enough about how great our experience was! Working with Linda and Courtney was easy and smooth. They were able to take what I envisioned and turn it into reality! Living in Chicago and planning a wedding in Florida was challenging, but they made it a smooth and as easy as possible experience! We also stayed there on our wedding night and the room and service was amazing!"The hotel to walk, stay and play around St. Auggie"Mar 23, 2012 traceme2kcIdeal place to stay when visiting St. Augustine. Walking distance orshort drive to many family fun attractions and adult suited fun too. If you're up for a good laugh and aren't easily offended, stop in at Trade Winds for down home music one evening. (No kiddos.) Or take in all the little locally owned boutiques close by. The pool is a quaint place. What's tops is they have a reciprocal deal with the private club on the beach, Seranata. There you can have your full of the beach with great service and food. They alao have an adult only pool area and loungers on the beach.. Just be sure to get your pass from the front desk before you go. It is a good 15 drive to go but worth it and there's a lot tosee on the drive in the way ofscenery. The only down on this hotel, and really, the only, is that the rooms are dim. Lights not bright enough. You will get the true essence of the coastal area with ease in access to area restaurants when this hotel is base. Goreguos views. Art in the hotel pretty enough to get you to stop and look every where you go. Gets hot and very humid during the day. Brig on the sun screen and a jacket for the evening dining. Don't miss the water side dinning! Experience the locals. Really liked the hotel for an all around good experience.My husband and I stayed here from 3/25 to 3/28. The hotel is beautiful and the staff is very friendly and helpful. Typical of Marriott Hotels such as these, parking is $22 per day (Valet is your only option) and wi-fi is not free. The first night we were here the firmness of the bed really hurt my hip joints, since I am a side sleeper. But after this night, I was fine. I guess I got used to it. I saw in other reviews that people didn't like the room sizes being on the smaller side and the walls to be thin. But I think it's important to remember that this is a historic building from 1888, and rooms of that time period were not as large or well insulated as people are used to today. Also, there is way to much to see and do in St. Augustine to be spending much time in the rooms anyways! I found our regular king bed room to be comfortable and spacious enough for the small amount of time we actually spent there, especially since much of that was sleeping! One of my annoyances with this location is that brunch was $30 per person, and we only learned of this price when we got the bill. Later we saw that the price was listed on a single piece of paper in our hotel room, but we wish the hotel would have been more up front with this, such as a sign or something near the restaurant. Yes, they had crab legs and other wonderful looking and good-tasting food, but by the time we filled up on our first plate we were too full to go back for more and so $30 was way too much for what we got. My other annoyance was the pool area. It is a nice spot once we found it, but there are no signs advertising where it was located. There were no towels available (luckily we brought our own), and my husband said it was ice cold. For the amount of money you pay to stay, why isn't it heated? For a change of temperature we went in the hot tub and that was so hot I felt ill after 5 minutes. I wanted to order a drink but there was no attendant available. When I was leaving I saw a sign on the wall that said to phone an attendant if you needed a drink or anything else. Who wants to get up and call for someone each time, especially while sunbathing? I think it would benefit the hotel to have someone out there at all times, and maybe even a little bar area. Overall I recommend a stay here, but skip the restaurants in the hotel and go exploring for other unique places such as the Cafe Alcazar across the street at the Lightner Museum.I mean, this place is nice, but it is freaking expensive, so it had better be.I frankly feel like they take advantage of the customer.  Be really careful here-- your room fee is not nearly what you'll actually be paying.Valet parking is $20, and I didn't see a reasonable alternative.  They don't let you just park yourself (that would be below them!).  When you check out, you find out there is another $20 "resort fee."  What is this for?  To give you access to a pool/beach resort in Ponte Vedra, like 20 minutes north of the hotel (oh and for "wireless internet).  Why in the hell would they MAKE you pay for this, even if you don't use it (and why would you use it when there is a closer beach in St. Augustine?)  And why do they not just include it in the room fee, so as not to be deceptive?When I ordered breakfast in bed in the morning, I got the cheapest thing on the menu-- just one $9 waffle.  I was a bit annoyed when I got a call at 9:00 AM asking if I really only wanted one waffle, if I was sure I didn't want a drink or another waffle.  Wasn't hoping for the wake-up call.  Then my $9 waffle came, and the bill was like $16 before gratuities.  There was a service fee and a delivery fee.  They just charge you with fees every possible chance-- I found it insulting.The walls were thin, so we could hear everything the people next door were saying.My honest impression is that they are just in it to get as much money out of you as possible, and I find that offensive.  Though the place is nice, it could be nicer.  Like much of St. Augustine, it just reeks of inauthenticity.  They take advantage of the city's amazing history to act like you should open your wallet and puke money at them, but I just don't understand what Casa Monica offered in return.  If you're looking to unload some money haphazardly, have fun here.  If you're more rational and don't like being taken advantage of, stay at the Holiday Inn.  It was only slightly less enjoyable, and like 1/3 the price.This hotel is really nice.  We had a good time there with the rosicrucian group.  It is a beautiful clean hotel with good service.
